keyFindings: Cook's purpose rhetoric follows a distinctive two-register pattern: utopian/epochal framing at all-hands meetings (survival + identity), measured commercial-success framing on earnings calls. The all-hands claims ('Apple must do this,' 'once-in-a-generation') are far more urgent than anything he says to analysts.

Apple's unique higher-calling claim — privacy as fundamental human right — does real organizational work by authorizing slower, more controlled AI rollout. It transforms competitive disadvantage (late to market) into moral superiority (we care about your rights).

The identity claims (PC before Mac, smartphone before iPhone) construct a historical pattern that reframes 'late' as 'deliberate.' This is a distinctively Apple rhetorical move with no equivalent in other specimens — no other CEO invokes three decades of corporate history to justify current AI timing.

Only one non-CEO claim (Federighi). Apple's purpose rhetoric is overwhelmingly Cook-centric, reflecting the company's centralized communication culture. Even on AI, Apple controls the message tightly.

Cook's tone shifted between Q3 FY2025 ('most profound technologies of our lifetime') and Q1 FY2026 ('creates great value'). The earlier framing was more epochal; the later is more commercial. This may reflect growing confidence in execution — less need for transformation rhetoric.
rhetoricalPatterns: Two-register communication: epochal for employees, measured for investors
Historical identity claims neutralize 'late to AI' narrative
Tight CEO-centric messaging — minimal other executive claims public
